newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico soybean demand high, record imports seen.
newsitem.headline: Mexico soybean demand high, record imports seen.

text.p: Demand for soybeans in Mexico remains very strong, and despite record high prices for beans, traders believe imports will surpass last cycle's 2.7 million tonne record.

"Even with the record high price of beans, the demand in Mexico is very strong according to United States and Mexico-based traders," the United Soybean Board and American Soybean Association (ASA) said in a update obtained Friday.
"Importers have ordered a record volume to date and if they execute current orders there will be a larger volume of imports than earlier expected for the marketing year," they said.

In the marketing year Sept 1 - Aug 31, a total of 1,875,000 tonnes has been imported up to April 9 from the United States, Mexico's traditional sole supplier of beans, although the amount of beans commited to be imported is put at 2,492,000 tonnes.

Traders said they did not expect high prices to trend down in the near future, that is until the start of the U.S. harvest. "Not even the beginning of the Argentine harvest is expected to push prices down," the USB-ASA said.
In a new and interesting trend, high prices have forced some importers to look to other sources of beans.
"One major oil crusher has confirmed the purchase of two boatloads of beans from South America that were quoted at $7 per tonne less than U.S. sources," the USB-ASA said.
The umbrella organisation said it had not been confirmed but the two shiploads are expected to be sourced from Brazil.
"If one crusher has already purchased beans from Brazil we can be assured that other crushers are looking for quotes from the south as well," the USB-ASA said.

One trader pointed out that although there might be more orders from South America, as of Aug 1, a tariff of 15 percent on beans from non-North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) countries comes into effect.
"This does not give a lot of time for importers to get vesels to Mexican ports before the tariff goes into effect," the USB-ASA said.
Meal prices in Mexico remain around 2,900 to 2,950 pesos per tonne (around $370/tonnes), but are likely to be raised soon because of pressure from higher bean prices, traders said.
